SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional bloating. These symptoms have been present for about five weeks. He has been experiencing shortness of breath during physical activities and slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour. He also has a slight cough, which he attributes to the change in seasons. The patient has been adhering to his medications but has struggled with his diet due to recent home renovations.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills. Positive fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Positive for occasional bloating and chest cramps. No significant weight gain or swelling.
• Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath and slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor daily weight and report any significant changes or worsening shortness of breath. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure appears well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was trying to change a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and stumbled, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, specifically over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation is present, and no pain is reported in the calves.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but everything else appears to be lined up properly.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide her with crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. He reports taking Tylenol, ibuprofen, and using icy heat, which did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, which resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoiding strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating suboptimal control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is monitoring his knee and managing symptoms.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam and follow-up of his chronic problems.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He states that his depression is well-managed.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting it on weekends. His blood pressure has been better controlled recently.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He denies any significant shortness of breath, except during high pollen counts and humid weather. He experiences some chest pounding during exertion while running 4-5 miles daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, endorses chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies significant shortness of breath.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Well-controlled at 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Depression:
• Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to contact if any concerns arise.

Prior Lobectomy:
• Medical Reasoning: No significant respiratory issues, exercising regularly.
• Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

Hypertension:
• Medical Reasoning: Improved control with Norvasc.
• Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current medication regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent backwards while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve within a week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a past medical history significant for iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She presents today after being unable to donate blood in December 2019 due to anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences cold intolerance and worsening anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and a colonoscopy approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses worsening anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Normal physical exam without any significant findings.

RESULTS

Blood work from 01/20/20 revealed low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, and low ferritin.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a past medical history significant for iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for further evaluation and management.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of anemia. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: We will recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks after continuing ferrous sulfate with orange juice for better absorption.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist for further evaluation and possible intravenous iron therapy or other treatments to improve iron storage.

Gastrointestinal evaluation.
• Medical Reasoning: To assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed, we will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy for the patient.
• Patient Education and Counseling: We will provide the patient with instructions for bowel prep and discuss the importance of these tests in evaluating her anemia.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward, a 52-year-old male, presents to the clinic for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for headaches included brain MRI and serology, which incidentally discovered the pituitary lesion. Pertinent labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrated a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 revealed a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. No other abnormalities were noted.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a gradual onset and worsening over the past three months. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. No other symptoms, such as fever, neck stiffness, numbness, or weakness, were reported. The patient has recently been bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None.

Family
Unknown, patient was adopted.

Social
Non-smoker, non-drinker, no recreational drug use.
Married for 25 years, works as a computer programmer.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule surgery for transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if any questions arise.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia. She presents as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient experienced chest pain in early October 2020, which lasted for four days. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. She also had difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient visited the ER, where she underwent an EKG and blood tests, both of which were normal. She has not had any chest pain since then. The patient has a history of gallbladder removal surgery.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower belly.

RESULTS

EKG and blood tests from the ER visit were normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing, which resolved after four days in October 2020. The ER ruled out heart issues with an EKG and blood tests. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient experienced a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain, which may have contributed to her symptoms.

The patient and doctor discussed the option of an EGD to investigate esophagitis, but given the lack of symptoms for the past three months, they decided to hold off on the procedure. The patient will self-monitor her symptoms and call the office if any additional episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms occur. If necessary, an EGD will be scheduled at that time. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting today for evaluation of kidney function. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic doctor, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned potential kidney anomalies associated with her syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Patient is well-nourished and slightly fussy during the exam.
• Genitourinary: Patient has 8-10 wet diapers per day, indicating normal urinary output.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting today for evaluation of kidney function.

• Medical Reasoning: Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome, including congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
• Additional Testing: We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up.
• Follow-up: The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

Patient Agreements: The patient's guardian understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. The patient reports severe pain, rated as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an Ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
Right Wrist: Obvious swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation, and bony crepitus. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a discussion with the patient regarding her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will wear the brace for six weeks and attend physical therapy three times per week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess the patient's progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan and attend all scheduled appointments. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office for further evaluation.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, on 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema.
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation on the medial aspect of the knee. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient reports slipping and falling, causing pain and swelling in the right knee.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of his diagnosis and x-ray results in detail.
- Medical Treatment: The patient will take ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily to reduce pain and inflammation. He will also wear a knee brace for support and ice the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times daily.

2. Hypertension
- Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril. His blood pressure today was 150/70 mmHg.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of a low-sodium diet and the need for a referral to a nutritionist to help manage his diet.
- Medical Treatment: The patient will continue taking 20 mg Lisinopril and will be referred to a nutritionist for dietary management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related. The patient is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains before that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to nearly fall. This occurs less than once a day and resolves quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for pain, as the issue does not last long. The patient is concerned about an upcoming trip involving walking and line dancing, and does not want to risk further injury.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies any other joint pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports taking blood pressure medication regularly.

Endocrine: Reports taking metformin for diabetes management.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Left knee exam - No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension management. Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Reports sore throat and decreased appetite, but no difficulty swallowing.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, likely related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide, as well as radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation dose of 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and lung crackles are likely due to inflammation from radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Inflammation in the esophagus may be contributing to the patient's symptoms.
- Medical Treatment: In addition to prednisone, prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger for a long time. No recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. Patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works in a family-owned donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness.

VITALS

Weight, heart rate, and temperature within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

IgA level found to be low.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low IgA level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without complications. Some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections, but this does not seem to be the case for the patient.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other antibodies and immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency with the patient and advised them to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control. Instructed the patient to inform any healthcare provider of their IgA deficiency if they ever require blood products.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Continue management with metformin and monitor blood sugar levels.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He has been doing a lot of pottery work recently, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is localized to the inside of his elbow and can radiate slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery work during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony misalignment.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the current symptoms and treatment plan. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is also instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. The patient is advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to assess progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain, initially thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes with difficulty finding a comfortable position. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain with minimal relief. The patient has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them in the past. His father also had a history of kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Urinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for additional pain relief.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain his urine and monitor for the passage of the stone.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to assess progress. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns during the treatment process.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The patient has been experiencing stinging, burning, and throbbing pain in the affected area. He also reports a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackening around the wound. The patient has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with some improvement in symptoms, but has recently developed cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak along his calf. He has also been experiencing coughing and shortness of breath.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher in the last few weeks, with some readings in the 300-400 range and one spike at 500-600. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently went on a hike with a new pair of diabetic shoes.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and shortness of breath.
Skin: Reports non-healing right foot ulcer with foul smell and drainage.
Musculoskeletal: Reports calf cramping and pain.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Within normal limits.
Heart rate: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Calf: Red streak along the calf, swelling, and pain.

RESULTS
Imaging

Right foot x-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes with recent blood sugar instability
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor redness and swelling in the calf closely.
5. Follow up in 7 days.
6. Recommend patient to follow up with endocrinologist for diabetes management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee with associated pain and erythema.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history reported.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and erythema.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort.
- Lung Auscultation: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Normal pedal pulses in right knee.
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema.
- Right knee: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella. Pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Bull's-eye rash present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Possible Lyme disease due to tick bite and associated symptoms.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with tick bite, erythema, and bull's-eye rash on right knee, which are concerning for Lyme disease.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.
- Medical Treatment: Start patient on doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.

2. Hypertension
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on lisinopril.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily.

3. Diabetes
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of diabetes and is currently on metformin.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order hemoglobin A1C to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
